{{pp-blp|expiry=22:40, 30 August 2019|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}}{{Infobox musical artist | name = 21 Savage | image = 21 Savage 2018.jpg | caption = 21 Savage performing in Austin, Texas in June 2018. | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1992|10|22|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]], U.S. | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] * [[Trap music|trap]] * [[gangsta rap]] }} | occupation = {{flatlist| * Rapper * singer * songwriter * record producer }} | instrument = Vocals | years_active = {{start date|2014}}–present | label = {{flatlist| * Slaughter Gang * [[Epic Records|Epic]] }} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Metro Boomin]] * [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] * [[Southside (record producer)|Southside]] * [[Sonny Digital]] * [[Zaytoven]] }} | website = {{URL|21savage.com}} }}
'''Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph''' (born October 22, 1992), better known by his stage name '''21 Savage''', is an American [[rapper]], record producer, and songwriter from [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. Abraham-Joseph grew up around criminality and eventually dropped out of school, beginning to rap in 2013 after the death of a friend. He gained attention in the [[Atlanta]] underground for the 2015 mixtape ''[[The Slaughter Tape]]'' before attaining nationwide attention following the [[Metro Boomin]] collaborative album ''[[Savage Mode]]'' (2016), its lead single "[[X (21 Savage and Metro Boomin song)|X]]", and his collaboration with Drake, "[[Sneakin']]".<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.interviewmagazine.com/music/21-savage-seth-rogen-interview|title=21 Savage chops it up with Seth Rogen|date=2018-04-26|work=Interview Magazine|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en-US}}</ref>
Abraham-Joseph released his debut studio album, ''[[Issa Album]]'', in 2017<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/the-break/2015/10/the-break-presents-21-savage/|title=The Break Presents: 21 Savage|last=C.M.|first=Emmanuel|date=October 9, 2015|work=[[XXL (magazine)|XXL Magazine]]|accessdate=May 2, 2018}}</ref> which debuted at number two on the ''Billboard'' 200 and gave Abraham-Joseph his first top twenty song, "[[Bank Account (song)|Bank Account]]." He achieved his first number one single at the end of 2017 with his feature on [[Post Malone]]'s "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]."<ref name="XXL Magazine2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/10/post-malone-21-savage-rockstar-no-1-billboard-hot-100-chart/|title=Post Malone's ''Rockstar'' Hits No. 1 on Billboard Hot 100 Chart|website=XXL Magazine|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> In 2017, he also released the [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] and Metro Boomin collaboration ''[[Without Warning (21 Savage, Offset and Metro Boomin album)|Without Warning]]''.
==Early life== Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph was born on October 22, 1992, in Atlanta, Georgia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/21-savage-mn0003515232/biography|title=Biography & History|last=Jeffries|first=David|website=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=February 22, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Birthplace2">{{cite web|url=https://schedule.sxsw.com/2016/events/event_MS37401|title=21 Savage|author=<!--Not stated-->|website=[[South by Southwest]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> He was raised by his mother Heather, who is of [[People of Dominica|Dominica]] descent, and his four brothers and six sisters, though one is deceased due to a shooting after a [[Illegal drug trade|drug deal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://djbooth.net/features/2016-11-22-brutal-story-behind-21-savage-dagger-face-tattoo|title=The Brutal Story Behind 21 Savage's Dagger Face Tattoo|last=James|first=Andy|date=November 22, 2018|website=[[DJBooth]]|access-date=May 2, 2018|quote=}}</ref>
In the seventh grade, Abraham-Joseph was banned permanently from every school in the [[DeKalb County School District]] due to gun possession.<ref>{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v1CmVcwIyKo|title=21 Savage Interview With The Breakfast Club (8-4-16)|date=August 4, 2016|people=[[Charlamagne tha God]], [[DJ Envy]]|publisher=[[The Breakfast Club (radio show)]]|location=[[New York City]]|access-date=May 6, 2018|medium=Video}}</ref> This led him to begin attending schools around the [[Atlanta metropolitan area]] before being sent to a youth detention center.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/everything-you-need-to-know-about-21-savage-news.22853.html|title=Everything You Need To Know About 21 Savage|work=HotNewHipHop|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref> After being released from the youth detention center, he completed eighth grade through an alternative program before finishing a semester of high school, dropping out in his freshman year following multiple exclusions which Abraham-Joseph said he was "exhausted" by.<ref name=":02">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thefader.com/2016/08/04/21-savage-the-breakfast-club-interview|title=21 Savage Talks Being An "A" Student, Losing His Best Friends On The Breakfast Club|work=The FADER|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref>
After dropping out, Abraham-Joseph joined a gang affiliated with the [[Bloods]]<ref name=":2" /> and became a full-time drug dealer, mainly selling cannabis.<ref name=":02" /> He also took parts in other criminal activities including robbery and grand theft auto regularly, though only being arrested once after contraband was found in a car he was driving.<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=https://www.gq.com/story/21-savage-profile-2018|title=21 Savage: From Robbin’ Season to Role Model|last=Wood|first=Samuel Hine, Geordie|date=2018-06-27|work=GQ|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> In 2011, when Abraham-Joseph was 19, he lost his "right hand" man, Larry in a shootout.<ref name=":02" /> In 2013, on his 21st birthday, Abraham-Joseph was shot six times and his brother Johnny "Tay-Man" was killed during an attempted robbery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2015/10/01/feature-21-savage|title=Meet 21 Savage, Atlanta’s Most Respected New Rapper|website=[[The Fader]]|access-date=August 24, 2017}}</ref>
==Career== ===2014–15: Early releases=== Following the death of his friend in a shootout on his 21st birthday, Abraham-Joseph began rapping, naming himself after the event<ref name=":12" /> though Savage came from Instagram predictions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.capitalxtra.com/features/facts/21-savage/|title=19 Facts You Need To Know About 'Rockstar' Rapper 21 Savage|work=Capital XTRA|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> His music career was originally subsidized by the uncle of his deceased friend, giving him money for studio time in 2013.<ref name=":2" /> On November 12, 2014, 21 Savage's debut single, "Picky", produced by DJ Plugg, was released. It was later included on his debut mixtape, ''[[The Slaughter Tape]]'', which was released on May 25, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemixtapes.com/mixtapes/34127/21-savage-the-slaughter-tape.html|title=21 Savage - The Slaughter Tape|work=LiveMixtapes|accessdate=April 27, 2016}}</ref> The release made him what [[Interview (magazine)|Interview]] called an "underground hero in Atlanta."<ref name=":2" />
On July 2, 2015, 21 released a collaborative EP, ''Free Guwop'', with [[Sonny Digital]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemixtapes.com/mixtapes/35036/21-savage-free-guwop-ep.html|title=21 Savage - Free Guwop EP|work=LiveMixtapes|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref> It is a tribute EP to fellow rapper and influence [[Gucci Mane]]. On December 1, 2015, Abraham-Joseph released his second mixtape, ''[[Slaughter King]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/21-savage-slaughter-king-new-mixtape.116157.html|title=21 Savage - Slaughter King - Download & Listen [New Mixtape]|author=Rose Lilah|date=2 December 2015|work=HotNewHipHop|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
===2016–present: ''Savage Mode'', ''Issa Album'' and ''Without Warning''=== [[File:21 Savage 2018 2.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:21%20Savage%202018%202.jpg|left|thumb|21 Savage in June 2018]] In June 2016, Abraham-Joseph was named as one of the "Freshman Class" of 2016 by ''[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2016/06/xxl-freshman-class-cover-2016/|title=XXL Freshman Class Cover 2016|last=|first=|date=June 13, 2016|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=[[Townsquare Media]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> On July 15, 2016, Abraham-Joseph released his joint [[Extended play|EP]] [[Savage Mode]] with Atlanta-based record producer [[Metro Boomin]]. The EP gained international success and peaked at number 23 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], which became their highest charting EP to date.<ref name="BB2002">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/7447109/21-savage/chart|title=21 Savage – Chart History: Billboard 200|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=July 29, 2016}}</ref> He was on the cover of [[Fader (magazine)|''Fader'']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/21-savage-and-futures-x-is-now-platinum-news.25668.html|title=21 Savage on the cover of Fader|last=Lilah|first=Rose|access-date=23 November 2016}}</ref> His single "[[X (21 Savage and Metro Boomin song)|X]]" featuring [[Future (rapper)|Future]] on the EP was confirmed by Billboard as going platinum in the US, being 21's 1st platinum record.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2016/11/21-savage-first-platinum-record-x/|title=21 Savage Gets His First Platinum Record With "X"|last=Weinstein|first=Max|date=November 22, 2016|website=|publisher=|accessdate=December 3, 2016}}</ref> On January 18, 2017, Abraham-Joseph announced that he had signed to [[Epic Records]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/news/id.42064/title.21-savage-inks-record-deal-with-epic-records#|title=21 Savage Inks Record Deal With Epic Records|accessdate=January 18, 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, his debut studio album, ''[[Issa Album]]'', reached at number two on the US ''Billboard'' 200 chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7866158/21-savage-haim-billboard-200-albums-chart-top-10|title=21 Savage & Haim Debut in Top 10 on Billboard 200 Albums Chart|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|date=July 16, 2017|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=July 17, 2017}}</ref> Its lead single, "[[Bank Account (song)|Bank Account]]", charted in the top 20 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://headlineplanet.com/home/2017/08/08/hot-100-niall-horans-slow-hands-enters-top-15-21-savages-bank-account-top-20/|title=Hot 100: Niall Horan’s "Slow Hands" Enters Top 15, 21 Savage’s "Bank Account" Top 20|date=August 7, 2017|work=Headline Planet|access-date=August 9, 2017}}</ref> Later that year, he was featured on [[Post Malone]]'s single "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]", which peaked at number one on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, and broke several records.<ref name="XXL Magazine2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/01/post-malone-rockstar-breaks-spotify-global-record/|title=Post Malone Breaks Spotify Global Record With ''Rockstar'' - XXL|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=2018-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8031270/post-malone-rockstar-platinum-21-savage|title=Post Malone & 21 Savage's 'Rockstar' Is Now Certified Platinum|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-02-16}}</ref>
In April 2018, Abraham-Joseph had a guest appearance on [[Young Thug]]'s extended play ''[[Hear No Evil (Young Thug EP)|Hear No Evil]]'' along with fellow rappers [[Nicki Minaj]] and [[Lil Uzi Vert]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2018/04/13/young-thug-hear-no-evil-nicki-minaj-21-savage|title=Young Thug drops Hear No Evil EP|last=Maicki|first=Salvatore|date=April 13, 2018|website=The Fader|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> Later that month he also appeared on the single "Outstanding" by [[SahBabii]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2018/04/sahbabii-21-savage-new-song-outstanding/|title=Listen to SahBabii and 21 Savage's New Song "Outstanding"|last=India|first=Lindsey|date=April 20, 2018|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> In March 21 he was featured on the single "Rover 2.0", which is part of [[BlocBoy JB]]'s [[Simi (mixtape)|Simi]] mixtape.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.stereogum.com/1988300/blocboy-jb-rover-2-0-feat-21-savage/music/|title=BlocBoy JB – "Rover 2.0" (Feat. 21 Savage)|last=Breihan|first=Tom|date=March 23, 2018|website=[[Stereogum]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|access-date=May 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2018/05/blocboy-jb-simi-mixtape/|title=BlocBoy JB Drops 'Simi' Mixtape Featuring Drake, Lil Pump and More|last=Coleman II|first=C. Vernon|date=May 4, 2018|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=May 9, 2018}}</ref> In the following month, he was featured on [[Ty Dolla Sign]]'s "Clout", which is part of the upcoming deluxe edition of last years's ''[[Beach House 3]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Darville|first=Jordan|date=May 9, 2018|title=Ty Dolla $ign recruits 21 Savage for "Clout"|url=http://www.thefader.com/2018/05/09/ty-dolla-sign-21-savage-clout|magazine=The Fader|location=New York City|access-date=May 11, 2018}}</ref>
On October 31, 2018, [[Halloween]], Abraham-Joseph posted on his Instagram a picture of a man in silhouette jumping in the air in the direction away from a large blaze. In the bottom right corner of the picture there is a "Parental Advisory" notice, as there oftentimes is on the cover of rap releases. Abraham-Joseph also tagged Metro Boomin in the post. For these reasons, some speculated it to be a sequel to 2017's ''Without Warning'' record. However, it turned out to be the cover for Metro’s debut solo album, ''[[Not All Heroes Wear Capes]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BpnfcqeBtAT/?hl=en&taken-by=21savage|title=Saint Laurent Don on Instagram: "y’all know what season it is @metroboomin 4L"|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-11-01}}</ref>
== Musical style == Called "one of the last street niggas left making music" by frequent collaborator Metro Boomin,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thefader.com/2015/10/01/feature-21-savage|title=Meet 21 Savage, Atlanta’s Most Respected New Rapper|work=The FADER|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> Abraham-Joseph's music is heavily autobiographic with emphasis on violent and criminal aspects of his past including murder and drug dealing.<ref name=":12" />
==Controversies== In 2018, 21 Savage reportedly started a movement called "Guns Down, Paintballs Up" which was intended to reduce gun violence.<ref name="CBS2">{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/paintball-wars-initially-intended-to-curb-gun-violence-linked-to-2-deaths/|title="Paintball wars," initially intended to curb gun violence, linked to 2 deaths|last=Diaz|first=Adriana|date=May 1, 2018|website=[[CBS News]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> The head of the [[Detroit Police Department]], [[James Craig (police chief)|James Craig]], described the movement as "well-intentioned, however, misguided".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/paint-up-guns-down-detroit-paintball-arrests-2018-04-27/|title=Detroit police cracks down on citywide "paintball wars"|author=<!--Not stated-->|date=April 21, 2018|website=CBS News|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/04/27/detroit-police-crack-down-citywide-paintball-wars/560019002/|title=Detroit police to crack down on citywide 'paintball wars'|last1=Patterson|first1=Brandon|last2=Zaniewski|first2=Ann|date=April 27, 2018|website=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> The movement has been linked to several cases of property crime and homicide.<ref name="CBS2" /><ref name="USA Today2">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/05/01/paintball-wars-spate-shootings/569407002/|title=Paintball shootings splatter cities after rapper calls for swapping handguns for paintball weapons|last1=Mensch|first1=Jessica|last2=Luthern|first2=Ashley|date=May 1, 2018|website=USA Today|publisher=Gannett Company|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> 21 Savage has not commented on the matter, although he paid for the funeral of a 3-year old who was killed in a related incident.<ref name="CBS2" /><ref name="USA Today2" />
Controversy arose after Abraham-Joseph pulled out a firearm during a pool party on June 11, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8460380/21-savage-gun-atlanta-brawl|title=21 Savage Draws Gun During Atlanta Pool Party Brawl|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> Abraham-Joseph was given the firearm by a friend after seeing an opposing crew member also pull out a pistol.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vibe.com/2018/06/21-savage-pull-out-a-gun/|title=21 Savage Pulls Out A Gun During A Brawl: Watch|date=2018-06-10|work=Vibe|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref>
==Personal life== Abraham-Joseph practices the African religion [[Ifá]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_us/article/zn4pn3/21-savage-breakfast-club-interview-2016|title=No Joke, You Should Definitely Watch 21 Savage's Entire 'Breakfast Club' Interview|last=Witmer|first=Phil|date=August 4, 2016|website=[[Noisey]]|publisher=[[Vice Media]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2016/11/21/21-savage-cover-story-interview|title=Savage World|last=Barshad|first=Amos|date=November 21, 2016|website=The Fader|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://pulse.ng/gist/21-savage-the-hottest-rapper-in-america-worships-ifa-id5816327.html|title=21 Savage, the hottest rapper in America worships Ifa|last=Tayo|first=Ayomide O.|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> In summer 2017, Savage started dating model [[Amber Rose]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/02/amber-rose-sniffs-21-savages-underwear/|title=Amber Rose Sniffs 21 Savage's Underwear When She Misses Him|last=Coleman II|first=C. Vernon|date=February 10, 2018|work=XXL Magazine|accessdate=February 10, 2018|publisher=Townsquare Media}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bet.com/music/2018/02/14/21-savage-valentines-day-gift-amber-rose.html|title=21 Savage Got The Sexiest Gift From Amber Rose For Valentine's Day|date=February 14, 2018|work=[[BET]]|accessdate=March 16, 2018}}</ref> As of March 2018, the couple has separated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/music/amber-rose-21-savage-split/|title=Amber Rose and 21 Savage Split After Nearly 2 Years of Dating|last1=Mizoguchi|first1=Karen|last2=Rubenstein|first2=Janine|date=March 14, 2018|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=March 15, 2018}}</ref>
He also has three children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalxtra.com/features/facts/21-savage/does-have-kids/|title=Does 21 Savage have any kids?|author=<!--Not stated-->|website=[[Capital XTRA]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref>
== Filmography == 21 Savage is currently working on his first movie, "'''''Issa Movie'''''".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ballerstatus.com/2017/12/10/21-savage-delivers-trailer-issa-movie/|title=21 Savage Delivers Trailer for "ISSA" Movie|date=2017-12-10|work=BallerStatus.com|access-date=2018-11-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
21 Savage also worked on a [[YouTube]] [[miniseries]] named "'''''Year 2100'''''".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/06/21-savage-animated-web-series-the-year-2100/|title=21 Savage Gets Animated in New Web Series ‘The Year 2100’ - XXL|website=XXL Mag|language=en|access-date=2018-11-04}}</ref>
==Discography== {{Main|21 Savage discography}}

{{autobiography|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 3D Na'Tee | image = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Samantha Davon James | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|12|18}} | birth_place = [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]] | origin = [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]] | death_date = | death_place = | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = [[Rapping|Rapper]] | instrument = | years_active = 1994–present | label = Already Legendary, BMB | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|www.3DNATEE.com}} }}
'''Samantha Davon James''' (born December 18, 1986), better known by her stage name '''3D Na'Tee''', is an American [[rapper]], songwriter, and video director. She was born in [[New Orleans, Louisiana]] and grew up in the [[3rd Ward of New Orleans|3rd Ward]]. 3D Na'Tee has been featured on several national media outlets such as [[MTV]],<ref>{{cite web|title=MTV: SuckaFree Freestyle: 3D Na'Tee|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/misc/651008/sucker-freestyle-3dnatee.jhtml|accessdate=May 8, 2011}}</ref> [[The Source (magazine)|The Source Magazine]],<ref name="thesource">{{cite web|title=THE SOURCE MAGAZINE: Top Up & Coming Female Rapper Releases Her Latest Project|url=http://www.thesource.com/articles/235038/}}</ref> [[XXL (magazine)|XXL Magazine]],<ref>{{cite web|title=XXL: Surviving The Times: Erick Sermon Talks About New Mixtape, Digital Label & Reviving Skills|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/features/2012/05/surviving-the-times-erick-sermon-talks-about-new-mixtape-digital-label-reviving-skills/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=SHAHEEM REID: 5 STAR REVIEW FROM XXL'S EDITOR-AT-LARGE SHAHEEM REID & @TEAMSHAHEEM|url=http://3dnatee.com/main/?p=1340}}</ref> The Fader Magazine,<ref>{{cite web|title=THE FADER MAGAZINE: Features 3D Na'Tee - Lil Kim|url=http://www.thefader.com/index.php?s=na%27tee&submit.x=0&submit.y=0&submit=Go}}</ref> RapRadar<ref>{{cite web|title=RAPRADAR: RapRadar Search Features|url=http://rapradar.com/?s=3D+na%27tee&x=0&y=0}}</ref> and RapRehab.<ref>{{cite web|title=RAPREHAB: RapRehab's Featured Artist|url=http://raprehab.com/2012/08/3d-natee-new-orleans/}}</ref> She has also received attention from Louisiana newspapers and music magazines.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE SMOKING SECTION: 3D Na'Tee is Back and we have been invited to her Coronation|url=http://smokingsection.uproxx.com/TSS/2012/07/3d-natee-the-coronation-mixtape}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=NOLA.COM: 4X Nola HipHop Award Winner 3D Na'Tee Raises The Bar Again By Being The First Native HipHop Artist With A Mobile App|url=http://www.nola.com/music/index.ssf/2011/09/industry_influence_celebrates.html}}</ref>
==Early life== In her middle school years, 3D Na'Tee honed her skills by what is called in New Orleans, ribbin' (rib - ing). Most people know this as "Playing the Dozens". Someone would start a beat by beating on a lunch room table or a garbage can, and off she went, lyrically attacking someone who was bold enough to test her skill. The rhymes were mostly about what they were wearing, how lame they were, or silly they looked.
In 1999, she began recording with local label called '''Clientell Records'''. Over the next five years, she would record multiple mixtapes under the "Snypa Squad" and feature on other projects Clientell Records came out with. However, in 2006, a year after [[Hurricane Katrina]], Clientell Records dismantled and 3D Na'Tee, who had previously established herself as a battler rapper amongst the local rap scene in New Orleans, released her first mix tape project '''"3's Company Vol.1: The Rapper, The Hustler, the Diva"''' followed by '''Volume 2''' in 2007. After the release of her second project, she appeared on '''The Kush 2''' DVD which was produced by [[YMCMB]] president [[Mack Maine]]. The DVD featured other Cash Money/Young Money artist like [[Lil Wayne]], [[Nicki Minaj]], and [[Birdman (entertainer)|Birdman]] as well as [[Curren$y]] of [[Warner Bros. Records]]
==Career== After the local success of her first two releases and her critically acclaimed appearance on '''The Kush 2''', she released her third mix tape '''Heavy Is the head That Wears The Crown''' followed by a music video for a song she titled, '''Guess Who's Coming 2 Dinner'''. That video piqued the interest of [[G-Unit Records]] affiliate and [[Shade 45]] [[Sirius Satellite Radio|Sirius XM]] radio host Nelson Gomez who invited her to [[New York City|New York]] for an interview on his XM show as well as on rapper [[50 Cent|50 Cents']] wildly popular ThisIs50.com website. Soon after, the talk of her third release also got her featured in HipHop Weekly Magazine by [[Benzino]], former co-owner of [[The Source Magazine]].<ref>{{cite web|title=3DNATEE.COM: BIO|url=http://3dnatee.com/main/?page_id=28}}</ref>
Because of video releases like Guess Who's Coming 2 Dinner which spoofed many mainstream hip hop artists, 3D Na'Tee's music has been described as controversial and sometimes offensive.<ref>{{cite web|title=WOMEN OF HIPHOP: 3D Na'Tee Explains How HipHop Saved Her Life, Talks Female Rap, and More|url=http://thewomenofhiphop.com/2012/08/04/wohh-exclusive-3d-natee-explains-how-hip-hop-saved-her-lifetalks-female-rap-more/}}</ref> That song also shared the title of her for mix tape released in 2010.
'''Guess Who's Coming 2 Dinner''' (The Mixtape) lead to 3D Na'Tee being nominated for a total of 5 Nola HipHop Awards by her in her home town at the NOLA Hiphop Awards.<ref>{{cite web|title=OFFBEAT MAGAZINE: Nola HipHop Awards Nominees Finalized|url=http://www.offbeat.com/2010/10/14/nola-underground-hip-hop-award-nominees-finalized/}}</ref> She won three awards (the most awards won by a single artist) for '''Lyricist of the Year''', '''Mixtape of the Year''', and '''Female Artist of the Year'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=ASHLEE NICOLE SPILLS: Winners of the 2010 HipHop Awards Announced|url=http://www.ashleenicolespills.com/2010/10/20/winners-of-the-2010-nola-underground-hip-hop-awards/}}</ref> The mixtape included collaborations from [[Curren$y]] (courtesy of Warner Bros. Records), '''Ebony Eyez''',<ref>{{cite web|title=STL TODAY: Ebony Eyez Returns With A Story 2 Tell|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/music/ebony-eyez-returns-with-a-story-to-tell/article_6a65d3ae-d2bb-11e1-985c-0019bb30f31a.html}}</ref> and '''Babs Bunny''' (formally of [[Sean Combs|Sean "Diddy" Combs]]) founded group, [[Da Band]].<ref>{{cite web|title=SYFFAL: Forming Da Band|url=http://www.syffal.com/making-the-band}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ALL MUSIC.COM: Da Band's Discography|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/da-band-mn0000764981}}</ref>
In early 2011 3D Na'Tee was featured on [[MTV|MTV's]] SuckerFree Freestyle<ref>{{cite web|title=MTV: SUCKERFREE FREESTYLE: 3DNATEE|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/misc/651008/sucker-freestyle-3dnatee.jhtml}}</ref> hosted by [[DJ Envy]]. 3D Na'Tee and Syleena collaborated on a song called '''Go Head'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=RHAPSODY: Syleena Johnson|url=http://www.rhapsody.com/artist/syleena-johnson/album/chapter-v-underrated/track/go-head-feat-natee}}</ref>
July 27, 2011 3D Na'Tee released a video for '''Switch'''<ref>{{cite web|title=WORLDSTARHIPHOP: 3D Na'Tee's Switch|url=http://hp-www.worldstarhiphop.com/videos/video800.php?v=wshhd71614snrClf6d9H&set_size=1}}</ref> which she shot and edited herself. The song included several previously released instrumental versions of songs produced by super producer [[Timbaland]]. This video gained her a nomination for '''Director of the Year''' and an award for '''Video of the Year'''. Because of the momentum the Switch video gained the day of its release, Timbaland viewed it online and in less than 24 hours, flew 3D Na'Tee to [[The Hit Factory|Miami's Hit Factory Studio]] to work with her on her next project, The Coronation.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE FADER MAGAZINE: 3D Na'Tee - Lil Kim|url=http://www.thefader.com/2012/07/30/video-natee-lil-kim/#comments}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ONWAX MAGAZINE: Rapper 3D Na'Tee shoots 'Wild' video in New Orleans, produced by Lex Luger|url=http://onwaxmagazine.com/owm/index.php/rapper-3d-natee-shoots-wild-video-in-new-orleans-produced-by-lex-luger/}}</ref> After several months spent traveling with Timbaland and other artist signed to his label, a contract was presented to 3D Na'Tee to sign to Timbaland's production company [[Mosley Music Group|Mosely Music Group]] and to be managed by members of Timbaland's management team. 3D Na'Tee and Timbaland later announced via [[Twitter]] that she was no longer a part of Timbaland's company because she decided not to sign the contract presented. In a later interview, 3D Na'Tee explained that there was no ill feelings towards Timbaland and cited her reasons for not signing were strictly because of contractual clauses that could not be agreed upon.<ref>{{cite web|title=DJSMALLZ.COM: INTERVIEW: SOUTHERN SMOKE TV! 3D NA'TEE (@3DNATEE) SPEAKS ON TURNING DOWN RECORD DEAL WITH TIMBALAND|url=http://www.djsmallz.com/blog/2012/5/18/interview-southern-smoke-tv-3d-natee-3dnatee-speaks-on-turni.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=WOMEN OF HIPHOP: [WOHH EXCLUSIVE]!|url=http://thewomenofhiphop.com/2012/08/04/wohh-exclusive-3d-natee-explains-how-hip-hop-saved-her-lifetalks-female-rap-more/}}</ref>
Exactly two years after 3D Na'Tee's last mix tape release, she released her highly anticipated street album ''The Coronation'' which featured artists like [[Keri Hilson]], Young Fletcher, and Lyrica Anderson. The Coronation also featured production from Mizay Entertainment's [[Lex Luger (producer)|Lex Luger]], [[Maybach Music Group|Maybach Music Group's]] Yung Shun, Heartbeatz, Casa Di, Versive Manhattan, Serious Beats, Da Smokestarz, among others.
In August 2012 it was announced by DJ Skee, Sirius Satellite Radio Host, that the first release from The Coronation entitled '''NO LOVE''' produced by [[Maybach Music Group|MMG's]] '''Young Shun''' was the #9 most requested song in the country.<ref>{{cite web|title=SIRIUS XM: #9 Song in the Country|url=https://twitter.com/DontHateBeHated/status/235174781102747648}}</ref> The Coronation's second release, '''Lil Kim''' produced by '''Casa Di''' gained tons of recognition as well as it was featured on both [[The Source (magazine)|The Source]] and [[The Fader]] Magazines' websites.<ref name="thesource" /><ref>{{cite web|title=FADER MAGAZINE: 3D Na'Tee Releases Lil Kim|url=http://www.thefader.com/2012/07/30/video-natee-lil-kim/#comments}}</ref> Lil Kim was a cautionary tale of a young girl with an absentee father who, because of her father's absence, unfortunately grew up and "fell in love" too fast. The song and its video (directed by Charley Mac), gained a lot of attention from tons of hiphop artist like [[Trina]], [[Missy Elliott]],<ref>{{cite web|title=WEBSTAGRAM: Trina Talks to 3D Na'Tee about 'Lil Kim|url=http://web.stagram.com/p/251601262639516075_14212753}}</ref> and Grammy Award Winning [[Chamillionaire]],<ref>{{cite web|title=BIG DOOR: Chamillionaire|url=http://www.bigdoor.com/company/press/grammy-award-winning-artist-and-bigdoor-ceo-to-speak-at-gamification-summit/}}</ref> who featured 3D Na'Tee's video on his famed social site [https://web.archive.org/web/20120802044043/http://www.chamillionaire.com/videos/play/608 www.chamillionaire.com].
==Discography==

{{Infobox professional wrestler |name = 911 |birthname = Alfred Poling |caption = Poling with fans in 2015 |image = |names = '''911'''{{cite web |url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/a/911.html |title=911's OWOW profile |publisher=Online World of Wrestling |access-date=2009-11-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091129035833/http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/a/911.html| archivedate= 29 November 2009 |deadurl=no}}
Al The Sledgehammer
Big Al
Sledge Hammer
Tombstone{{cite web |url=http://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=602 |title=911 - Wrestlers Database |accessdate=11 August 2012}} |height = {{height|ft=6|in=8}} |weight = {{convert|300|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1957|01|22}} |birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] |resides = [[West Creek, New Jersey]], [[United States]] |billed = |trainer = [[Larry Sharpe (wrestler) | Larry Sharpe]] |debut = 1990 |retired = 2006 }} '''Alfred Poling''' (born January 22, 1957) better known by the [[ring name]] '''911''', is an American retired [[Professional wrestling|professional wrestler]], best known for his time with [[Extreme Championship Wrestling]] (ECW) between 1994 and 1996. ==Professional wrestling career== ===Early career=== Poling was trained as a wrestler by [[Larry Sharpe (wrestler) | Larry Sharpe]]. He debuted in 1990, wrestling on the [[independent circuit]] under the [[ring name]] "Al the Sledgehammer".{{cite web |url=http://www.1softball.com/WBS/WrestlingBookingSheet291.htm |title=The Wrestling Booking Sheet - Issue #291 |first=Steve |last=Appenrodt |date=1999-08-30 |accessdate=2013-08-30}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c7gHi_sgkAw |title=IWA Championship Wrestling - Derrick Dukes vs Al The Sledgehammer |first=Rob |last=Russen |year=1990 |accessdate=2013-08-30|publisher=[[YouTube]]}} ===Extreme Championship Wrestling (1994-1996)=== Poling achieved his greatest national exposure in [[Extreme Championship Wrestling|Eastern Championship Werstling]] (ECW) in the mid-1990s. He debuted in ECW as an unnamed "handler" to [[Sabu (wrestler)|Sabu]] on the January 18, 1994 episode of ''[[ECW Hardcore TV|Eastern Championship Wrestling]]'' by defeating [[Chad Slivenski|Chad Austin]]. He joined [[Paul Heyman]]'s [[Dangerous Alliance]] [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#stable|stable]] with Sabu and [[Tazz|The Tazmaniac]]. His [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Gimmick|gimmick]] was as an enforcer of the "extreme" attitude; he was named '''911''' at ''The Night The Line was Crossed'' on February 5, where he defeated Chad Austin in a rematch. As part of his monstrous persona, he would frequently perform the [[chokeslam]] on others with little provocation, which made him quickly [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#over|popular]] with the crowd as a [[Face (professional wrestling)|fan favorite]].{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2004/11/24/pf-729421.html|title=SLAM! Speaks: What we miss about ECW|author=SLAM Wrestling staff|publisher=SLAM Wrestling|accessdate=February 16, 2015|date=November 25, 2004}} He received his first title shot in ECW at ''When Worlds Collide'', where he challenged [[Mikey Whipwreck]] for the [[ECW World Television Championship|ECW Television Championship]] but got disqualified after chokeslamming the [[Referee (professional wrestling)|referee]]. He would then enter a [[Feud (professional wrestling)|rivalry]] with [[Curtis Hughes|Mr. Hughes]], whom he defeated at [[Hardcore Heaven (1994)|Hardcore Heaven]]. On August 27, at the [[NWA World Title Tournament]], 911 participated in the [[ECW tournaments#NWA World Heavyweight Championship Tournament|namesake tournament]] for the vacant [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]], where he defeated [[Doink the Clown]] in the quarter-final after four chokeslams, before losing to [[2 Cold Scorpio]] in the semi-final.{{cite book|title=Hardcore History: The Extremely Unauthorized Story of ECW|author=Williams, Scott E.|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing, Inc|year=2013|chapter=5}} He closed the year by defeating [[The Pitbulls]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Handicap match|handicap match]] at [[Holiday Hell (1994)|Holiday Hell]]. Poling received the ''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]'' [[PWI Rookie of the Year|Rookie of the Year]] award due to his enormous popularity in ECW for the year 1994. Poling had two big matches in 1995, scoring wins over [[Ron Simmons]] at [[Hostile City Showdown (1995)|Hostile City Showdown]] and [[Jim Steele (wrestler)|Jim Steele]] at ''Barbed Wire, Hoodies and Chokeslams''. At the [[House Party (1996)|1996 House Party]] [[List of ECW supercards and pay-per-view events|event]], 911 teamed with [[Rey Mysterio|Rey Misterio, Jr.]] to defeat [[The Eliminators]] in a [[Professional wrestling tag team match types|tag team match]], which would turn out to be his last match in ECW. He got involved in a brawl with [[Tazz|Taz]] after the match and a feud evolved between the two, but it was scrapped as Poling left the promotion by early 1996 after a falling out backstage with Paul Heyman over the former's treatment of the ring crew.{{cite book|title=Hardcore History: The Extremely Unauthorized Story of ECW|author=Williams, Scott E.|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing, Inc|year=2013|chapter=10}} ===World Championship Wrestling (1996-1997)=== Poling wrestled in [[World Championship Wrestling]] (WCW) in 1996 and 1997, under the names Tombstone,{{Cite episode |title= WCW Monday Nitro|series= WCW Monday Nitro|serieslink= WCW Monday Nitro|station= TNT (TV channel)|airdate= 1996-12-23}} Sledge Hammer{{Cite episode |title= WCW Saturday Night|series= WCW Saturday Night|serieslink= WCW Saturday Night|station= TBS (TV channel)|airdate= 1997-02-15}} and Big Al.{{Cite episode |title= WCW Saturday Night|series= WCW Saturday Night|serieslink= WCW Saturday Night|station= TBS (TV channel)|airdate= 1997-01-11}}{{Cite episode |title= WCW Saturday Night|series= WCW Saturday Night|serieslink= WCW Saturday Night|station= TBS (TV channel)|airdate= 1997-04-12}}{{Cite episode |title= WCW Saturday Night|series= WCW Saturday Night|serieslink= WCW Saturday Night|station= TBS (TV channel)|airdate= 1997-05-10}} Poling did not portray the Big Al who feuded with [[Tank Abbott]] in WCW in early 2000. ===Return to ECW=== In 1998, Poling returned to ECW at [[UltraClash (1998)|UltraClash]] in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, [[chokeslam]]ming [[Bill Wiles]]. Poling was then accompanied by manager Judge Jeff Jones, who proclaimed 911 to be the true giant of professional wrestling. They were then interrupted by [[Spike Dudley]] and had an [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#impromptu match|impromptu match]], which 911 lost in [[Squash (professional wrestling)|under a minute]]. ===Independent circuit=== Throughout the late 1990s, 911 appeared with the [[New Jersey]] based [[Jersey All Pro Wrestling]] promotion, winning the [[JAPW Heavyweight Championship]] on two occasions. He made an appearance at [[Pro-Pain Pro Wrestling]] ''A War Renewed'' on June 29th, 2002 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, interfering on the behalf of [[Tod Gordon]] and [[Sabu (wrestler)|Sabu]], delivering a chokeslam to [[Sandman (wrestler)|Sandman]] (who had just been betrayed by his partner, [[Bill Alfonso]]). At ''[[Hardcore Homecoming]]'' in 2005 he chokeslammed both [[Danny Doring]] and [[Roadkill (wrestler)|Roadkill]]. He wrestled at New York Wrestling League in 2008. ==Personal life== Poling resides in [[West Creek, New Jersey]]. ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''All American Wrestling Alliance''' **AAWA Heavyweight Championship (1 time) *'''[[Jersey All Pro Wrestling]]''' **[[JAPW Heavyweight Championship]] ([[JAPW Heavyweight Championship#Title history|2 times]]) *'''New Jack City Wrestling''' **NJCW Heavyweight Championship (2 times) *'''[[List of National Wrestling Alliance territories|NWA New Jersey]]''' **[[NWA New Jersey State Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA New Jersey State Heavyweight Championship#Title history|2 times]]) **[[NWA World Light Heavyweight Championship (New Jersey version)|NWA World Light Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA World Light Heavyweight Championship (New Jersey version)#Title history|1 time]]) *'''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''' **[[PWI Rookie of the Year|Rookie of the Year]] (1994) ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Portal|Professional wrestling}} *{{IMDb name|id=1407632|name=Al Poling}} {{DEFAULTSORT:911}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:American male professional wrestlers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Professional wrestlers from New York (state)]] [[Category:Professional wrestling managers and valets]] [[Category:Sportspeople from New York City]] [[Category:The Dangerous Alliance members]]

'''Acting under a description''' is a conception of the [[intentionality]] of human action introduced by philosopher [[G. E. M. Anscombe]].
==G. E. M. Anscombe== Anscombe wrote that a human action is intentional if the question "Why?", taken in a certain sense (and evidently conceived as addressed to him), has application (''Intention'', par. 5-8).<ref>{{citation |first=Gertrude |last=Anscombe |author-link=G. E. M. Anscombe |title=Intention |publisher=Harvard University Press |year=1957}}</ref> An agent can answer the "Why?" question by giving a reason or purpose for her action. "To do Y" or "because I want to do Y" would be typical answers to this sort of "Why?"; though they are not the only ones, they are crucial to the constitution of the phenomenon as a typical phenomenon of human life (sections 18-21). The agent's answer helps supply the descriptions under which the action is intentional. Moreover, the act is known without observation (''Intention'', section. 28). For example, a person knows without observation that their hands are pushing upwards and when asked what they are doing, they say they are opening the window. Hence, in their hands pushing upwards, they are opening the window; opening a window being a description of the intentional act.
Anscombe was the first to clearly spell out that actions are intentional under some descriptions and not others. In her famous example, a man's action (which we might observe as consisting in moving an arm up and down while holding a handle) may be intentional under the description "pumping water" but not under other descriptions such as "contracting these muscles", "tapping out this rhythm", etc.
==Ian Hacking== The implications of this philosophy of intentional action were extended by [[Ian Hacking]].<ref>{{citation |first=Ian |last=Hacking |author-link=Ian Hacking |title=Rewriting the Soul: Multiple Personality and the Sciences of Memory |publisher=Princeton University Press |year=1995}}</ref> His argument is as follows: people talk about themselves as intentional beings. Descriptions of acts are almost always descriptions of how an act was intended. A person offers an explanation of why he or she acts thus and so. The array of descriptions available to an individual depend on the descriptions available to the society in which the individual resides. Hence, the media, the expertise of psychologists, physicians and scientists as well as the folk understandings of cultural communities all provide descriptions; descriptions that can be assumed by an individual as he or she acts.
Acting under a description has important implications for interpreting our selves.<ref>{{Citation |last=Sugarman |first=Jeff |year=2009 |title=Historical ontology and psychological description |periodical=Journal of Theoretical and Philosophical Psychology |volume=29 |issue=1 |pages=5–15}}</ref> Self-understanding involves understanding our acts and hence understanding the descriptions under which we act. This issue has been illustrated with discussions of particular cases such as autism and multiple personality disorder. In contemporary society, the descriptions under which people act constitute the kind of act and the kind of person that commits the act.<ref>{{Citation |last=Hacking |first=Ian |year= 2007 |title=Kinds of People: Moving Targets |periodical=PROCEEDINGS-BRITISH ACADEMY |volume=151 |pages=285}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |last=Curran |first=R |year=1997 |title=HACKING, IAN. Rewriting the Soul: Multiple Personalities and the Sciences of Memory |periodical=Journal of Analytical Psychology |volume=42 |issue=1 |pages=174–177}}</ref> By illustration, a child pushes another child in the playground. If asked why he did that, he might answer "to show who's boss", "because I have ADHD", or "because I was provoked". Hacking is not concerned with which description best suits the act, but rather, how the descriptions under which people act depend on the descriptions available to them.
According to Hacking, selves are formed not only by humans' bio-physical constitution and the events we experience, but also by the descriptions we ascribe to the events that occur and the events we engage in. These descriptions are often causal descriptions: explanations of how we have come to be the persons that we are. A person does not come to be the person that she is simply because the events of her past caused her to be this person. Rather, the descriptions attributed to events in the past are a formative influence on her being. These explanations are replete with meaning and causal attribution. People are substantially (though not entirely) the people they understand themselves to be.
Acting under a description also has important implications for our interpretation of different societies and different eras. Hacking argues that descriptions change as the shared understandings of particular acts change. Hacking provides the following example. 17th-century courtiers tickled the genitalia of Louis XIII. Were they guilty of child abuse? The description of child abuse available in the 21st century did not exist in the 17th century. "In short, the charge of child abuse may be true of the past, but it was not true in the past. The description only becomes true with time. For Hacking, retroactive descriptions are, at the very least, controversial."<ref>{{Citation |last=Sugarman |first=Jeff |year=2009 |title=Historical ontology and psychological description |periodical=Journal of Theoretical and Philosophical Psychology |volume=29 |issue=1 |pages=5–15}}</ref>
The past is indeterminate, not because acts simply may or may not have happened, but because the ascribed causes of those acts form an ever-shifting account depending on the ebb and flow of descriptions readily ascribed to those acts as the practices of society change.<ref>{{Citation |last=Lynch |first=M |year=1995 |title=Review Symposium on Ian Hacking: Narrative Hooks and Paper Trails: the Writing of Memory |periodical=History of the Human Sciences |volume=8 |issue=4 |pages=118}}</ref>
==See also== * ''[[Rewriting the Soul]]'', a book-length study by Hacking of multiple personality disorder

'''Ahmad Aali''' ({{lang-fa|احمد عالی}}, (born 1935 in [[Tabriz]]) is an [[Iran]]ian photographer and artist.

{{refimprove|date=July 2015}} '''Animat''' (''third-person indicative present of the [[Latin]] verb '''animō'''''),<ref>[http://www.verbix.com/webverbix/go.php?D1=9&H1=109&T1=animo "Animo" at Verbix Latin Verb Conjugator]. Retrieved July 22, 2015.</ref> meaning to "animate, give or bring life".<ref>[http://latin-dictionary.net/search/latin/animo "Animo" at Latdict Latin Dictionary and Grammar Resources]. Retrieved July 22, 2015.</ref>
'''Animats''' are artificial [[animal]]s, a contraction of [[animal]]-materials. The term includes physical robots and virtual simulations. Animat research, a subset of [[Artificial Life]] studies, has become rather popular since [[Rodney Brooks]]' seminal paper "Intelligence without representation". The word was coined by S.W. Wilson in 1985, in "Knowledge growth in an artificial animal", published in the first ''Proceedings'' ''of an International Conference on Genetic Algorithms and Their Applications''.
An example using the Animat model as proposed by Wilson is discussed at some length in chapter 9 of [[Stan Franklin]]'s book, [[Artificial Minds]]. In this implementation, the animat is capable of independent learning about its environment through application and evolution of pattern-matching rules called "taxons".
In 2001 Thomas DeMarse performed studies on '[[neurally controlled animat]]'. Every two years, the Society of Adaptive Behaviour meets and produces a proceedings on this topic. They also have a journal, ''[[Adaptive Behavior]]''.
[[Alan H Goldstein]] has proposed that, because [[nanobiotechnology]] is in the process of creating real animal-materials, speculative use of this term should be discouraged and its application become purely phenomenological. Based on the Animat Test (contained in the reference "I, Nanobot.") any nonbiological material or entity that exhibits the minimum set of behaviors that define a life form is, de facto, an Animat. Goldstein's basic premise is that in the age of nanobiotechnology it is necessary to follow the chemistry and molecular engineering rather than watching for the emergence of some pre-conceived minimum level of 'intelligence' such as an artificial neural network capable of adaptive phenomena. Goldstein has cautioned that there is a serious disconnect between the fields of nanobiotechnology and A-life based on profound differences in scientific training, experimental systems, and the different sets of terminology (jargon) these two fields have produced. Nanobiotechnologists (really molecular engineers who work with both biological and nonbiological molecules) are generally not concerned with complex systems per se; even when they are building molecular interconnects between such systems, e.g. neuroelectronic splices. A-Life researchers mainly take a systems-level approach. The enormous transformative power of novel molecular engineering has the potential to create Animats, true nonbiological life forms, whose relatively simple behavior would not fit into most standard A-Life paradigms. As a result, Goldstein argues, the first Animats may come into being completely unrecognized by either scientific community.
==See also== *[[Cultured neuronal network]]s *[[Hybrot]] *[[Pacrat]]

"I, Nanobot." Salon.com, March 9, 2006. *S. W. Wilson, Knowledge growth in an artificial animal. In Proceedings of an International Conference on Genetic Algorithms and Their Applications (pp. 16–23), Grefenstette, J.J., ed., Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Assoc. (1985). http://www.eskimo.com/~wilson/ps/KGAA.pdf *S. W. Wilson. The animat path to AI. In J.-A. Meyer and S. Wilson, editors, From Animals to Animats, pages 15–21. MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, 1991. http://www.eskimo.com/~wilson/ps/animat.pdf

{{Use British English|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox person | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Wolverhampton]], [[England]] | image = | caption = | death_date = | birth_name = | occupation = Actor | nationality = British | years active = 2009–present | website = {{url|http://www.AntonioAakeel.com/}} }}
'''Antonio Aakeel''' is an English actor. He was named by [[Screen International]] as a 2018 Star of Tomorrow for his leading role in ''[[Eaten by Lions (film)|Eaten by Lions]]'' and appeared opposite [[Alicia Vikander]] in Warner Bros.' ''[[Tomb Raider (film)|Tomb Raider]]'' reboot.<ref>{{cite web |title=Stars of Tomorrow |url=https://www.screendaily.com/features/stars-of-tomorrow-2018-antonio-aakeel-actor/5133183.article |website=Screen Daily |accessdate=8 November 2018 |ref=Screen International}}</ref> He is known for appearing in the [[BAFTA]] award-winning series ''[[Three Girls (miniseries)|Three Girls]]'', ''[[Skins (UK TV series)|Skins]]'' and was cast alongside [[Riz Ahmed]] in the 2016 thriller ''[[City of Tiny Lights]]''.
== Early life == Aakeel was born in [[Wolverhampton]], [[England]], and moved around the [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands]] as a child.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wolverhampton actor secures feature-length international film role|url=http://nativemonster.com/film-and-theatre/film/wolverhampton-actor-secures-feature-length-international-film-role|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=NativeMonster}}</ref> He caught the acting bug after being given a one-line role in a school nativity play and went on to hone his craft through local theatre, before being scouted by a talent agent.<ref>{{cite news|title=Birmingham actor makes Hollywood Debut|url=http://whatsonlive.co.uk/birmingham/news/birmingham-actor-makes-hollywood-debut/36060|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=What's On Birmingham}}</ref> He speaks [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] and [[Hindi]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Interview with Antonio Aakeel|url=http://scottishasianmagazine.com/interview-antonio-aakeel/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Scottish Asian Magazine}}</ref>
== Career ==
===Film===
Aakeel starred as Nasir Baloch in the 2013 political short film ''[[The Line of Freedom (film)|The Line of Freedom]]'' directed by David Whitney. The film depicts the true story of a murdered student rights activist and premiered at the [[Dubai International Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite news|title=The Line of Freedom Premiere|url=https://dubaifilmfest.com/en/films/23961/the_line_of_freedom.html|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Dubai Film Festival}}</ref> Upon its release, the film was immediately met with controversy and allegedly resulted in Aakeel becoming a target of death threats.<ref>{{cite web|title=Where Is The Mainstream Coverage Of The Crisis In Balochistan?|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/where-is-the-mainstream-coverage-of-the-crisis-in-balochistan_us_57da9edee4b0d5920b5b25b2|website=Huffington Post|accessdate=16 Sep 2016}}</ref> The film was subsequently prohibited in Pakistan and reportedly contributed to a national ban of [[IMDb]].<ref>{{cite news|title=The Line of Freedom and the brief IMDb ban in Pakistan|url=https://globalvoices.org/2013/12/01/the-line-of-freedom-and-the-brief-imdb-ban-in-pakistan/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Global Voices}}</ref>
In 2015, he appeared as Raza in feature film ''[[The Contract (2015 Film)|The Contract]]'', written by [[David Marconi]] and directed by Nic Auerbach.
He was cast alongside [[Riz Ahmed]] and [[Billie Piper]] in London crime thriller ''[[City of Tiny Lights (film)|City of Tiny Lights]]'' directed by [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] winner [[Pete Travis]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet the young cast of City of Tiny Lights|url=http://screenterrier.blogspot.co.uk/2016/09/meet-young-cast-of-city-of-tiny-lights.html|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=ScreenTerrier}}</ref> The film had its world premiere at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] 2016 and released in UK cinemas April 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=Popular Birmingham actor to make big screen debut|url=https://iambirmingham.co.uk/2016/07/15/birmingham-actor-to-make-big-screen-debut/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=I Am Birmingham}}</ref>
In December 2016, Aakeel landed a supporting role in ''The Hungry'', [[Film London| Film London's]] contemporary feature adaptation of [[Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] [[Titus Andronicus]] alongside [[Naseeruddin Shah]] and [[Tisca Chopra]], directed by Bornila Chatterjee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet the Birmingham actor who has been cast in an international Shakespeare film|url=http://stylebham.com/life/meet-birmingham-actor-cast-international-shakespeare-film|accessdate=20 Jan 2017|publisher=StyleBham}}</ref> The Film premiered under special presentations at the 2017 [[Toronto International Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Hungry - TIFF|url=http://www.tiff.net/tiff/the-hungry/|website=tiff.net|accessdate=12 September 2017}}</ref>
It was announced in March 2017 that Aakeel will star as the lead in British feature film ''[[Eaten by Lions (film)|Eaten by Lions]]'', starring opposite comedians [[Johnny Vegas]] and [[Jack Carroll (comedian)|Jack Carroll]], directed by Jason Wingard.<ref>{{cite news|title=Antonio Aakeel to star as lead in British feature Eaten by Lions|url=http://www.identityschoolofacting.com/antonio-aak%CE%BE%CE%BEl-announced-as-lead-role-in-new-feature-eaten-by-lions/|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=IAG}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=BHAM MAIL|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/film-news/billie-piper-helps-peaky-blinders-12848465|accessdate=23 April 2017}}</ref>
Aakeel appeared opposite [[Academy Awards|Oscar]]-winning actress [[Alicia Vikander]] in the franchise reboot ''[[Tomb Raider (film)|Tomb Raider]]'' (2018), directed by [[Roar Uthaug]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Birmingham actor Antonio Aakeel to star with Alicia Vikander in Tomb Raider re-boot|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/film-news/tomb-raider-antonio-aakeel-alicia-12848465|website=Birmingham Mail|accessdate=14 June 2017}}</ref>
===Television===
Aakeel landed his first television role in the British series ''[[Skins (UK TV series)|Skins]]''. He was chosen over 500 hopefuls by director [[Charles Martin (director)|Charles Martin]] and appeared in series 3 of the [[E4 (TV channel)|E4]] drama.<ref>{{cite web|title=Antonio Aakeel - NewUrban|url=http://www.new-urban.co/antonio-aakeel/|publisher=NUBI|accessdate=31 October 2016}}</ref>
He has gained guest-lead roles in [[BBC]] series ''[[Doctors (2000 TV series)|Doctors]]'' and [[BBC One]] drama series ''[[Moving On (TV series)|Moving On]]'' directed by [[Reece Dinsdale]].<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC Doctors|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04bmv4j/credits|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=BBC}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Antonio Aakeel will star in BBC series Moving On|url=http://us4.campaign-archive1.com/?u=ae8e3d09be1e9c6b15ce45e66&id=68475a4b7a|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Identity Drama}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Moving On returns as BBC One reveals new commissions|url=http://www.prolificnorth.co.uk/2016/10/moving-on-returns-as-bbc-one-reveals-new-commissions/|website=Prolific North|accessdate=31 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=BBC's Doctors to explore gender identity issues for the first time|url=http://www.gaytimes.co.uk/culture/52307/bbcs-doctors-explore-gender-identity-issues-first-time/|accessdate=31 October 2016|publisher=GayTimes.co.uk}}</ref>
In 2016, Aakeel was cast in ''Guilty Pleasures'' directed by Sonny Michael Chohan, a TV drama pilot based on real life [[sex trafficking]] circles in the [[UK]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Child grooming drama to premiere in Birmingham|url=https://iambirmingham.co.uk/2016/08/08/child-grooming-drama-premieres-in-birmingham/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=I Am Birmingham}}</ref>
In May 2017 he appeared in the three-part [[BBC One]] drama ''Three Girls'' directed by [[BAFTA]] winner [[Philippa Lowthorpe]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Antonio Aakeel set to appear in BBC drama|url=http://www.asianimage.co.uk/news/14841782.Antonio_Aakeel_set_to_appear_in_BBC_drama__Moving_On_/|website=Asian Image|accessdate=3 Nov 2016}}</ref>
===Theatre===
In 2013, he played the title role in the stage adaptation of ''Guantanamo Boy''. The play ran at the [[Half Moon Theatre]] and toured nationally at [[Middle Temple|Middle Temple Hall]], [[Almeida Theatre]], [[The Hat Factory]], [[Mercury Theatre, Colchester|Mercury Theatre]], [[Burnley Youth Theatre]] and [[The Drum (Arts Centre)|The Drum Theatre]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Review: Guantanamo Boy|url=https://www.halfmoon.org.uk/review-guantanamo-boy-childrens-theatre-reviews/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Children's Theatre Reviews}}</ref> [[The Stage]]'s Susan Elkin wrote Aakeel "is great as the distraught, anguished, terrified Khalid. The downhill spiral followed by the final return of a damaged-for-life boy to Rochdale is well handled too. He has a very expressive face."<ref>{{cite news|title=Guantanamo Boy Theatre Review - WhatsonStage Susan Elkin|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/reviews/11-2013/guantanamo-boy_32626.html|accessdate=23 August 2016|publisher=WhatsonStage.com}}</ref>
In 2015, he played the lead role of Artie in ''Waiting for Garbo'' at the [[Crescent Theatre]] as part of the Birmingham Theatre Festival. Love Midlands Theatre reviewed the performance, commenting his "portrayal of a brash New Yorker falling apart is utterly convincing."<ref>{{cite news|title=Waiting For Garbo Theatre Review|url=http://www.lovemidlandstheatre.co.uk/reviews/a-play-that-leaves-you-thinking|accessdate=23 August 2016|publisher=Love Midlands Theatre}}</ref>
Antonio has also performed locally with [[The Midlands|Midlands]] based theatre company Round Midnight.<ref>{{cite news|title=Follow me theatre play a success|url=http://redditchstandard.co.uk/news/round-midnights-follow-success-redditch/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=The Redditch Standard}}</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} '''Artificial creation''' is a field of research that studies the primary synthesis of complex lifelike structures from primordial lifeless origins.
The field bears some similarity to [[artificial life]], but unlike artificial life, artificial creation focuses on the primary emergence of complex structures and processes of abiogenesis. Artificial creation does not rely exclusively on the application of [[evolutionary computation]] and [[genetic algorithms]] to optimize artificial creatures or grow synthetic life forms. Artificial creation instead studies systems of rules of interaction, initial conditions and primordial building blocks that can generate complex lifelike structures, based exclusively on repeated application of rules of interaction.
An essential difference that distinguishes artificial creation from other related fields is that no explicit [[fitness function]] is used to select for fit structures. Structures exist based only on their ability to persist as entities that do not violate the system's rules of interaction. Artificial creation studies the way in which complex [[emergent properties]] can arise to form a [[self-organizing system]].
==Origins==
Although concepts and elements of artificial creation are represented to some degree in many areas, the field itself is less than a decade old. There are models of self-organizing systems that produce emergent properties in [[biology]], [[computer science]], [[mathematics]], [[engineering]] and other fields. Artificial creation differs from these in that it focuses on underlying properties of systems that can generate the endless environmentally interactive complexity of living systems.
One of the primary impetuses for the exploration of artificial creation comes from the realization in the [[artificial life]] and [[evolutionary computing]] fields that some basic assumptions common in these fields represent subtle mischaracterizations of natural [[evolution]]. These fall into two general classes: 1) there are fundamental problems with the use of [[fitness functions]] for the primary synthesis of complex systems, and 2) the process of [[self-replication]] used in almost all artificial life research is not a fundamental property of [[self-organizing systems]].
==Issues==
The concept of a [[fitness function]] (or [[objective function]]) is central to [[artificial life]] systems. The [[fitness function]] is used to drive a given [[artificial evolution]] process to create [[synthetic organisms]] capable of performing a given task. However, [[fitness functions]], even aggregate high-level ones, drive evolving systems to particular solutions and place a ceiling on innovation and complexity. Natural [[evolution]] does not drive organisms toward particular solutions to problems. There is no motive force for [[evolution]] in our universe beyond that of adherence to physical law. This is a subtle point: when modern organisms are viewed in a local context it does appear that they are evolving to optimize particular abilities that will help them survive. This is not the case in a global sense. In fact, the pressure to optimize a given ability comes from the current state of a given population. The only fundamental selective pressure is the ability of structures to adhere to physical law. [[Stochastic]] events initiated the appearance of features that we might view as adaptive traits, and it is the local evolution of these traits that much of evolutionary theory is based upon.
The universe maintains its own consistency. However, when trying to model the universe, or create [[artificial organisms]] by mimicking natural evolution, the application of [[fitness functions]] that select for particular abilities force an unnatural bias onto the evolving organisms.
In [[evolutionary biology]], it is well understood that all properties of organisms and [[ecosystems]] are [[emergent properties]] of fundamental physical law. The conceptual problems related to generations, offspring and populations that occur in [[artificial life]] systems stem from the fact that self-replication is itself an innovation of life on Earth. The dynamics observed in modern self-replicating life forms on Earth are extremely complex [[emergent properties]] of the organisms themselves, not driving forces imposed by an external controlling entity.
==References== {{cite book | last = Howard | first = Ted | authorlink = |author2=Rifkin, Jeremy | title = Who should play God? : the artificial creation of life and what it means for the future of the human race | publisher = Dell Publ. Co | date = 1977 | location = | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-440-19504-7 }}

{{redirect|L-form|the bacterial strains|L-form bacteria}} [[File:Chirality with hands.svg|300px|thumb|Two [[enantiomer]]s of a generic [[amino acid]] that are chiral]] [[File:Zwitterion-Alanine.png|thumb|right|300px|(''S'')-Alanine (left) and (''R'')-alanine (right) in zwitterionic form at neutral pH]] '''Chirality''' {{IPAc-en|k|aɪ|ˈ|r|æ|l|ɪ|t|i}} is a geometric property of some molecules and ions. A chiral molecule/ion is non-superposable on its [[mirror image]]. The presence of an [[asymmetric carbon|asymmetric carbon center]] is one of several structural features that induce [[chirality]] in organic and inorganic molecules.''Organic Chemistry'' (4th Edition) Paula Y. Bruice. Pearson Educational Books. {{ISBN|9780131407480}}''Organic Chemistry'' (3rd Edition) Marye Anne Fox, James K. Whitesell Jones & Bartlett Publishers (2004) {{ISBN|0763721972}}{{GoldBookRef|title=Chirality|file=C01058}}{{GoldBookRef|title=Superposability|file=S06144}} The term ''chirality'' is derived from the [[Ancient Greek]] word for hand, χεῖρ (''kheir''). The mirror images of a chiral molecule or ion are called [[enantiomer]]s or '''optical [[isomer]]s'''. Individual enantiomers are often designated as either [[Dextrorotation and levorotation|right-handed or left-handed]]. Chirality is an essential consideration when discussing the [[stereochemistry]] in [[organic chemistry|organic]] and [[inorganic chemistry]]. The concept is of great practical importance because most biomolecules and pharmaceuticals are chiral. Chiral molecules and ions are described by various ways of designating their [[absolute configuration]], which codify either the entity's geometry or its [[polarimetry|ability to rotate plane-polarized light]], a common technique in studying chirality. == Definition == Chirality is based on [[Molecular symmetry|molecular symmetry elements]]. Specifically, a chiral compound can contain no [[improper axis of rotation]] (S''n''), which includes planes of symmetry and inversion center. Chiral molecules are always dissymmetric (lacking S''n'') but not always asymmetric (lacking all symmetry elements except the trivial identity). Asymmetric molecules are always chiral.Cotton, F. A., "Chemical Applications of Group Theory," John Wiley & Sons: New York, 1990. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |+ Molecular symmetry and chirality |- ! Rotational
axis (C''n'') || colspan="3" | Improper rotational elements (''S''n) |- |  || '''Chiral'''
